global.developer_prompt: This is a pipeline to write sections of an NSF grant proposal about how bugs of the past predict pests of the future. In answering all questions do not make up any information, provide direct truthful statements, do not elaborate or write flowery language. For each section you write, if relevant, make sure it tries to meet these program description requirements: 1) Geosciences Advancement: How do the proposed activities contribute to advancing geosciences research and/or education in response to motivating science drivers? 2) AI Impact: What novel integration of AI is proposed, and does it overcome significant methodological and/or capacity bottlenecks that inhibit research progress in the geosciences? Partnerships: Does the proposal include mechanisms to develop meaningful interdisciplinary partnerships to support the intended Geosciences Advancement and AI Impact? Will partnerships benefit all project participants, including pathways for cross-training students and other researchers in the methods to be pursued?

files.prompt: This is an entire research paper, analyze it for title, author list, and create a citation that will be used later. Otherwise summarize the paper in terms of the relevant aspects related to an NSF grant proposal about

project_summary.developer: The Project Summary must contain a summary of the proposed activity suitable for dissemination to the public. It should be a self-contained description of the project and should contain a statement of objectives and methods to be employed. It should be informative to other persons working in the same or related fields, and, insofar as possible, understandable to a scientifically or technically literate lay reader. The Project Summary must not include any proprietary/confidential information
project_summary.user_template: Write no more than one page of text for the project summary
project_summary.assistant_template: This summary should be based on {project_narrative_context}

project_narrative_core_content.developer:
Project Description – Core Content

Clearly state the project’s objectives, significance, and relationship to current knowledge and ongoing research. Outline the general plan of work, including the rationale, methods, and procedures. Explain what will be done, why it is important, how success will be measured, and potential benefits if successful. Integrate both technical aspects of the research and broader contributions (e.g., educational, societal).
project_narrative_core_content.user_template: Write this section referencing {project_narrative_context}, following the instructions in {project_narrative_core_content.developer}. If you are missing any information, insert a placeholder in ALL CAPS for the authors to fill in later. Ensure you incorporate the required subheadings for the three Specific Requirements (Geosciences Advancement, AI Advancement, Partnerships).
project_narrative_core_content.assistant_template: Use {project_narrative_context} to provide a cohesive narrative; if any required info is not in {project_narrative_context}, prompt the authors for it.

project_narrative_broader_impacts.developer:
Broader Impacts

Provide a distinct heading titled ‘Broader Impacts.’ Discuss how the project’s activities will contribute to broader goals such as inclusivity in STEM, improved education, public engagement, workforce development, partnerships, and other societally relevant outcomes.
project_narrative_broader_impacts.user_template: Write this section referencing {project_narrative_context} and following {project_narrative_broader_impacts.developer}. If insufficient information is available, create placeholders. Include any relevant details about inclusivity, education, and outreach.
project_narrative_broader_impacts.assistant_template: Refer back to the background in {project_narrative_context} to illustrate how broader impacts are integrated. For missing details, leave placeholders in ALL CAPS.

project_narrative_data_management.developer:
Data Management and Sharing

In the Special Information/Supplementary Documentation section, describe plans for data preservation, documentation, and sharing of research products.
project_narrative_data_management.user_template: Explain the data management plan. If no data-sharing strategy is detailed in {project_narrative_context}, leave a placeholder.
project_narrative_data_management.assistant_template: Reference relevant data sources mentioned in {project_narrative_context} and show how you plan to manage them. If details are missing, prompt the authors.

project_narrative_international_involvem.developer:
International/Foreign Organization Involvement

If the proposal includes funding for an international institution or collaborator, explain and justify that partnership in the Project Description.
project_narrative_international_involvem.user_template: If there is any international component indicated in {project_narrative_context}, detail it here. Otherwise, leave a note that none is currently planned.
project_narrative_international_involvem.assistant_template: Mention any cross-border collaborations found in {project_narrative_context}. If not applicable, insert a placeholder indicating no international collaborations.

project_narrative_page_limitations.developer:
Page Limitations

The Project Description (including up to five pages for Results from Prior NSF Support) must not exceed 15 pages in total. URLs should not be included.
project_narrative_page_limitations.user_template: Remind authors of the 15-page limit. If any part of the narrative seems too long, prompt them to shorten or move details to appendices if allowed.
project_narrative_page_limitations.assistant_template: Incorporate a note on how to keep the text concise while referencing all critical components from {project_narrative_context}.

project_narrative_prior_support.developer:
Results from Prior NSF Support (If Applicable)

Provide information on relevant NSF awards from the past five years or current support. Include: Award number, amount/period of support, project title, outcomes (with separate Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts subheadings), publications, and relation of completed work to the new proposal. Use up to five pages for this section if needed.
project_narrative_prior_support.user_template: If you have prior NSF support details in {project_narrative_context}, summarize them here. If not, use a placeholder.
project_narrative_prior_support.assistant_template: Include any known NSF awards from {project_narrative_context}, otherwise leave placeholders in ALL CAPS for authors.

project_narrative_unfunded_collaboration.developer:
Unfunded Collaborations

If the proposal involves significant collaboration with individuals not in the budget, describe the collaboration in the Facilities/Equipment/Other Resources section. Provide letters of collaboration in supplementary documentation.
project_narrative_unfunded_collaboration.user_template: List all known collaborations from {project_narrative_context} not directly in the budget. If missing, prompt the authors.
project_narrative_unfunded_collaboration.assistant_template: If any key partnership from {project_narrative_context} is not budgeted, detail it here. Otherwise, insert placeholders.

project_narrative_group_proposals.developer:
Group Proposals

Interdisciplinary group proposals must adhere to the 15-page limit unless a deviation is approved in advance.
project_narrative_group_proposals.user_template: If this is a group proposal, make sure to note the interdisciplinary nature and mention the page limit constraints. If not applicable, leave a placeholder.
project_narrative_group_proposals.assistant_template: Reference the team composition in {project_narrative_context} if this is interdisciplinary. Otherwise, insert placeholder.

project_narrative_renewed_support.developer:
Proposals for Renewed Support

Follow the guidelines for renewal proposals, describing how previous work connects to the new proposed research.
project_narrative_renewed_support.user_template: If this proposal renews previous NSF-funded work, summarize that connection. If not applicable, leave a placeholder.
project_narrative_renewed_support.assistant_template: Include how the project builds on previous work mentioned in {project_narrative_context}. If not applicable, note that here.

project_narrative_instructions.developer: Use these references to fill in each section of the narrative. If there is information in the context that cannot be used, place it under 'unused outline info' and explain why you couldn't use it. If any required detail is missing, use a placeholder in ALL CAPS.
project_narrative_instructions.user_template: Combine all sections into the final narrative, referencing each part as needed. If you discover unused information, create a section called 'unused outline info'.
project_narrative_instructions.assistant_template: Guide authors to properly reference {project_narrative_core_content}, {project_narrative_broader_impacts}, and other sections as relevant.

project_narrative_context.developer: Initial project plan and background details, including discussion of geoscience data, AI approaches (Convolutional neural nets, KGML, PRITHVI), interdisciplinary team information, and references. Also includes: Novel use of earth observation data, climate variation, pest evolutionary ecology, trait data, historical contexts, etc.
project_narrative_context.user_template: Refer to this context as the main source of project background. If something is missing, prompt the authors to provide it.
project_narrative_context.assistant_template: This is the foundation for all sections. Ensure each requirement (Geosciences Advancement, AI Advancement, Partnerships) is addressed if possible.

bibliography.developer: Provide a bibliography of any references cited in the Project Narrative. Each reference must include the names of all authors (in the same sequence in which they appear in the publication), the article and journal title, book title, volume number, page numbers, and year of publication. Include only bibliographic citations. Applicants should be especially careful to follow scholarly practices in providing citations for source materials relied upon when preparing any section of the application. Please click the add attachment button to the right of this field to complete this entry. Reference information is required. Each reference must include the names of all authors (in the same sequence in which they appear in the publication), the article and journal title, book title, volume number, page numbers, and year of publication. (See also Chapter II.D.2.d(iii)(d)) If the proposer has a website address readily available, that information should be included in the citation. It is not NSF's intent, however, to place an undue burden on proposers to search for the URL of every referenced publication. Therefore, inclusion of a website address is optional. A proposal that includes reference citation(s) that do not specify a URL is not considered to be in violation of NSF proposal preparation guidelines and the proposal will still be reviewed. Proposers must be especially careful to follow accepted scholarly practices in providing citations for source materials relied upon when preparing any section of the proposal. While there is no established page limitation for the references, this section must include bibliographic citations only and must not be used to provide parenthetical information outside of the 15-page Project Description.
bibliography.user_template: Write the bibliography as described and cite the papers provided
